channel.title: Nature VS Nurture
channel.description: What do you think about this matter? Which do you think is dominant in most individuals?

item.title: Nature VS Nurture
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller

At first sight at the Title I thought it said “Nature VS Nature”

Read full topic

item.title: Nature VS Nurture
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:18, topic:286821”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=379313.msg2852845#msg2852845 date=1246647264]

[quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=379313.msg2852825#msg2852825 date=1246646897]

Cody, I don’t think we should continue our conversation on Locke’s and Hobbes’ theories. It will undoubtedly get nowhere, because there has been no scientific proof of either theory, so Locke’s, Hobbes’, yours, and my statements are all opinionated, which proves nothing.
[/quote]You’ve discovered what a debate is. ++ ;]

To be honest, the greatest of philosophs would get nowhere without opinionated discussion. Scientific proof has nothing to do with the power of though and belief, because what lies in science is only what has already been proven.

Yeah, and I think you mean ‘philosophers’.
[/quote]No actually, I don’t. Philosophs is a word, spell checker is just an asshole.[/quote]
http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/philosoph

Read full topic

item.title: Nature VS Nurture
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:11, topic:286821”][quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=379313.msg2852705#msg2852705 date=1246640995]

[quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=379313.msg2852699#msg2852699 date=1246640742]

[quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=379313.msg2852696#msg2852696 date=1246640575]

That brings in John Locke and Thomas Hobbes.

John Locke believing that all humans are born moderately good, and Thomas believing that we’re born evil.

All humans are born evil, whether you agree or disagree.
[/quote]It’s a historical fact that what you said is completely an opinion. No argument, because it’s been debated before between those two philosophers before. I, unlike you, believe that we were all morn moderately “well” or “neutral”. We’re here with a clean slate, effected only by outside influences. Obviously we wouldn’t thrive as well as we are now without one another. This discussion could go on for a long time.

If a human is born, and there are no influences around the human, good or bad, that human would turn into a savage in order to survive.
[/quote]Then how are we not savages? Do remember, we all started from one. One without another? Although you could consider the “Adam and Eve” story. But there still wasn’t a society. They didn’t work as a team like your interpreting. You never know that someone didn’t step up out of the rest of the savages and think “We need to make tools, think, etc.” Either way, there would have been revolution as there has been in the past. The future elevates, not escalates.

We still are savages, but the environment around us has taught us to suppress this aspect of us. Thus, without the environment and resources, we do not learn to suppress this aspect.
[/quote]We’ve had our environment since day 1. We’ve been together hand in hand, so how would it be impossible to break away from our “inner savage” when you say the environment subdues us.

The environment cannot conquer us; it only quells some of our natural savagery.[/quote]Never said it will conquer us, I’m just saying we adapt to it. It has an influence on us that we attach ourselves to. We survive from what we create from our environment, in which case we’d have to learn. If you have instinct with intelligence, you’re not a savage.

Read full topic

item.title: Nature VS Nurture
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:9, topic:286821”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=379313.msg2852699#msg2852699 date=1246640742]

[quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=379313.msg2852696#msg2852696 date=1246640575]

[quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=379313.msg2852692#msg2852692 date=1246640264]

That brings in John Locke and Thomas Hobbes.

John Locke believing that all humans are born moderately good, and Thomas believing that we’re born evil.

All humans are born evil, whether you agree or disagree.
[/quote]It’s a historical fact that what you said is completely an opinion. No argument, because it’s been debated before between those two philosophers before. I, unlike you, believe that we were all morn moderately “well” or “neutral”. We’re here with a clean slate, effected only by outside influences. Obviously we wouldn’t thrive as well as we are now without one another. This discussion could go on for a long time.

If a human is born, and there are no influences around the human, good or bad, that human would turn into a savage in order to survive.
[/quote]Then how are we not savages? Do remember, we all started from one. One without another? Although you could consider the “Adam and Eve” story. But there still wasn’t a society. They didn’t work as a team like your interpreting. You never know that someone didn’t step up out of the rest of the savages and think “We need to make tools, think, etc.” Either way, there would have been revolution as there has been in the past. The future elevates, not escalates.

We still are savages, but the environment around us has taught us to suppress this aspect of us. Thus, without the environment and resources, we do not learn to suppress this aspect.
[/quote]We’ve had our environment since day 1. We’ve been together hand in hand, so how would it be impossible to break away from our “inner savage” when you say the environment subdues us.[/quote]
The environment cannot conquer us; it only quells some of our natural savagery.

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:10, topic:286821”]I would just like to introduce the book “Lord of the Flies”, I have to read for exam and it places young children from nurtured backgrounds on a desert island and basically most of them turn into savages. This just shows that you can return to your natural savagery if you are abandonned from civilisation.

The environment has not affected us… We just realised that some things are right and wrong. Humans did the change.[/quote]
I agree with this. In The Lord of the Flies, Ralph, a civilized individual, ends up displaying his nature side, because of the malignant conditions and environment.

Read full topic

This just shows that you can return to your natural savagery if you are abandonned from civilisation.

The environment has not affected us… We just realised that some things are right and wrong. Humans did the change.

We still are savages, but the environment around us has taught us to suppress this aspect of us. No argument, because it’s been debated before between those two philosophers before. I, unlike you, believe that we were all morn moderately “well” or “neutral”. We’re here with a clean slate, effected only by outside influences. Obviously we wouldn’t thrive as well as we are now without one another. This discussion could go on for a long time.

item.title: Nature VS Nurture
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

If all members of a society acted and lived based on solely nature, our population would not survive long. All humans are born evil, whether you agree or disagree. It is up to our environment to educate us so we are able to act based on nurture and nature with equilibrium. Most individuals act based on nurture because it’s the way they have been raised and because they want to suppress their true evil side that is contained within them.

Read full topic

item.title: Nature VS Nurture
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:286821”]I personally think nature should always come before nurture because natural responses and actions are done sub-conscientiously and only occur when your brain and body thinks its right. On the other hand Nurture is something that someone’s normally forced into your head, so you end up trying to think about something and waste so much energy doing a simple task. Normally this involves trying to physically stop yourself doing something natural.[/quote]I totally agree. Nurture doesn’t necessarily mean anything good. It’s a way of raising, so if you were raised to be racist, you’re going to be racist. Say you were born on an island with no other race; naturally you wouldn’t be racist because you wouldn’t know anything about another race.

You basically catch on to anything you’re taught via nurture, and fate takes you via nature. So, learn the truth on your own, or risk being mislead?..

Answering the OP though–
Sadly, everyone is influenced by the media, their parents, and everything else that comes appealing to them. As long as a higher power gives them the nurturing, it’s “right”.

Read full topic

item.title: Nature VS Nurture
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I personally think nature should always come before nurture because natural responses and actions are done sub-conscientiously and only occur when your brain and body thinks its right. On the other hand Nurture is something that someone’s normally forced into your head, so you end up trying to think about something and waste so much energy doing a simple task. Normally this involves trying to physically stop yourself doing something natural.

Read full topic
